awd_titl_txt: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Sensing, Modeling and Optimization of Postoperative Heart Health Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Postoperative outcomes are critical to the quality of life of many patients.  However, after discharge, there are currently few sensor-based decision support systems extending to home, workplace, and community. Postoperative care primarily depends on episodic follow-up visits and rare electrocardiograms. Very little has been done to continuously monitor clinical parameters of postoperative patients, estimate clinical status, and further help optimal management of postoperative recovery. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supports fundamental research to develop a collaborative sensing, statistical modeling and decision-making strategy for optimizing postoperative management of heart health.  This research will help clinicians and patients leverage the fast development of sensing and mobile technology to achieve a substantial boost in smart postoperative management.  As a result, this project will provide education on heart-healthy living and raise the awareness of smart health.  In addition, realizing a better postoperative care will achieve a reduction in healthcare costs.  A broader impact in education will be realized through new curriculum modules, training of healthcare professionals, and recruitment of under-represented students.

In current practice, ad hoc strategies are widely used for managing postoperative risks.  This award will make possible a new sensor-based, patient-centered management of heart health that can overcome several limitations of existing practices. In particular, it will empower clinicians and patients to (1) quantitatively measure the quality of life before and after cardiac procedures, (2) optimize postoperative cardiac care and decrease arrhythmia recurrences, and (3) improve lifestyle modifications and positively influence general postoperative outcomes.  If successful, this research will lead to new data imputation algorithms to tackle uncertainty in patient-centered sensing, extract sensor-based biomarkers of cardiac risks, model the evolving dynamics of cardiac conditions, and optimize postoperative management under uncertainty. The success of this project will invoke a new "sensing-modeling-optimization" approach to theoretically formulate relationships connecting physiological signals from postoperative patients, useful information from analytical models with smart postoperative health management. Analytical methods and tools will be generally applicable to handle data veracity, feature extraction, risk prognostics, and process optimization in sensor-based monitoring and control of cardiovascular systems.

por.por_cntn:
American Heart Association projected that 40.5% of the US population will have some form of heart disease by 2030, and direct medical costs will reach $818.1 billion.  The number of cardiac procedures performed is about 51.4 million every year in the US.  Postoperative care is critical to improving the quality of life of heart patients. The objective of this research project is to develop a collaborative sensing, statistical modeling and decision-making strategy to optimize postoperative cardiac care.  This research was collaborated with cardiologists and physicians at the James A Haley Veterans Hospital.

When patients are moved into an intensive care unit (ICU), clinicians and nurses will diligently monitor a number of clinical variables such as blood pressure, heart rate, gas exchange, pulse oximetry and metabolic panel. However, heterogeneous types of sensing and measurement methods often result in data uncertainty and incompleteness. Missing values are not uncommon for clinical variables relevant to a patient's health conditions. This adversely affects data-driven decision making in the healthcare environment. There is an urgent need to go beyond the existing clinical practices and to develop advanced analytical methods that will help tackle the challenges of ICU data uncertainty and incompleteness, thereby extracting pertinent knowledge about clinical status from heterogeneous healthcare recordings. We have developed a novel nested Gaussian process (NGP) model that is tailored to represent multi-dimensional covariance structure of time, variable and patient for high-dimensional data imputation in healthcare systems. The final results are published in IISE Transactions Health Systems Engineering 2019.

In addition, dementia is a general neurodegenerative disorder beyond normal aging, which is not only overwhelming for post-operative patients, but also negatively affects their caregivers and families. In the state of the art, paper-based survey methods such as Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) and Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) are widely used for the assessment of dementia conditions. However, these methods require the lab visits or administrations from nurses, physicians and examiners, and are limited in the ability to track temporal degradation (or daily variations) of dementia conditions. With rapid advances in sensing technology, there are increasing interests on the development of new sensor-based methods that provide more flexibility in dementia monitoring and require minimal interventions from practitioners. Our team developed a new sensor-based method that estimates the dementia conditions with daily locomotion data. The final results are published in IISE Transactions Health Systems Engineering 2019.

This project has generated significant research results, including more than 23 Journals or Juried Conference Papers, 1 PhD Dissertation,  7 best poster/paper awards, 1 Erickson Discory Grant for REU research, and 1 finalist in the best student paper competition, with all products directly related to this award. Students who directly worked on this project, co-mentored by the PI and co-PI, received multiple tenure-track faculty position offers as a result of their very productive research training, attests to the training and professional development opportunities provided by this project.

Results of this project provide enabling methods and tools to help clinicians and patients achieve smart post-operative health management. This positively impacts cardiovascular patients and those who are with neurodegenerative disorders, the largest population at risk of death in the US and in the world. Project outcomes/results/conclusions are broadly disseminated through presentations, sessions, and seminars to the INFORMS, IEEE, IISE, healthcare, and the lay communities.
